oai_dc:dc.dc:title: WPA workers at Standing Stone State Park
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Group of men, all wearing overalls, in front of the 12-foot rock that gave the state park its name. At front row, right, a man holds a puppy. Photograph is a laser copy in sepia.

By the 1930s, the park area on the Cumberland Plateau was plagued by soil erosion and sub-marginal lands. The Work Projects Administration (WPA), Civilian Corservation Corps (CCC), Resettlement Administration, and U.S. Forest Service worked together to; make the land productive again. The WPA and CCC were work-relief programs that brought much-needed jobs during the Great Depression. The FDR administation's ""alphabet agencies"" were New Deal projects created to alleviate poverty and spur the economy.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: People; Men; Children; Boys; Dogs
